title: Protocol to establish a lung adenocarcinoma immunotherapy allograft mouse model with FACS and immunofluorescence-based analysis of tumor response

Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
KrasLox-STOP-Lox(LSL)-G12D;Trp53flox/flox; ZsGreenflox/flox mouse model
Timing: 8 weeks
This section describes how to induce autochthonous tumors in genetically engineered mouse models (GEMMs).
Package lentivirus.
HEK293T cell line is cultured and maintained in 10 cm petri dish using 10 mL DMEM (GIBCO) supplemented with 10% Fetal Bovine Serum (FBS, HyClone) and 100 U/mL penicillin-streptomycin (GIBCO) at 37°C and 5% CO2 in a humidified Thermo fisher incubator.
Produce lentivirus by cotransfecting 293T cells at 70%–80% confluency with 4 μg Lenti-LucOSCre(Addgene,#22777), 3 μg psPAX2 (Addgene, # 12260), and 1.5 μg pMD2.G (Addgene, # 12259)(DuPage et al., 2011[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]). 1 μg/μL polyethylenimine (PEI) solution was used as transfection reagent, the transfection process are as follows.
Mix the plasmids (9 μg in total) with 1 mL FBS free DMEM, stand for 5 min at 25°C.
Add 27 μL (3 times the mass of plasmids) PEI solution to the plasmids-DMEM mixture, and stand for 15 min at 25°C.
Add the transfection mixture to petri dish dropwise.
Change medium within 18 h post transfection, given that viruses are produced around 18 h. Harvest supernatants containing viral particles 48 h after the medium change by collecting the supernatants in a 15-mL sterile tube. Keep everything on ice at all times.
Pellet nonadherent cells and cell debris by centrifugation at 1600 × g at 4°C for 10 min and pass the supernatant through a sterile, 0.45-μM low-protein binding filter(Joshi et al., 2015[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]).
Critical: To obtain high-quality lentivirus, HEK293T should be at rapid growth stage, and the cells should be transfected at 70%–80% confluency.
Concentrate viral particles by ultracentrifugation.
Transfer approximately 10 mL lentiviral supernatant to SW-41 ultracentrifuge tubes containing 1.5 mL of 20% sucrose cushion in PBS (w/v). Perform this step slowly to avoid mixing the layers.

Bring a scale into the biosafety cabinet and balance the tubes in the metal bucket. by adding media with virus particles until the tubes are at no more than 0.01 g apart in weight and are filled until 2 mm from the top (also see Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).
Concentrate lentiviral particles by centrifugation in an SW-41 rotor at 100000 × g for 2 h at 4°C (the virions will be in the pellet at the bottom of the tube).
Remove the supernatant carefully!
Resuspend the pellet in 200 μL of 1× HBSS buffer.
Immediately titrate the samples and prepare 50 μL aliquots. The aliquots can be stored at −80°C for at least 1 years.
Clean the biosafety cabinet with 10% bleach and then 70% EtOH. Treat the used pipettes and tips with 70% EtOH from biohazardous contamination.
Critical: This whole process should be performed on ice to maintain the viability of virus. Concentrated virus should be stored at −80°C in single-use aliquots to avoid freezing and thawing (Troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.1]).
Lentivirus titration
Titrate lentivirus using the qPCR Lentivirus Titration Kit following the manufacturer’s instructions: https://www.abmgood.com/qpcr-lentivirus-titration-titer-kit-lv900-vin.html[href=https://www.abmgood.com/qpcr-lentivirus-titration-titer-kit-lv900-vin.html]
For functional titration, titrate lentiviruses expressing Cre by infecting the CAG-Loxp-mCherry-Loxp-ZsGreen cell line (termed the Cre reporter).
Seed 1×104 Cre reporter cells with 100 μL DMEM complete medium in a 96-well plate.
Serially dilute the virus 10-fold and replace the medium with 100 μL diluted virus. Count the number of ZsGreen-positive cell colonies 3 days after the medium change.
Use the two smallest colony numbers to calculate the titer with the following formula: titer = (smallest colony number × dilution rate + the second smallest colony number × dilution rate) ×100/2 TU/mL.
Lung Intratracheal intubation (also see the Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1])

Sedate a KrasLox-STOP-Lox(LSL)-G12D;Trp53flox/flox; ZsGreenflox/flox mouse (6–8 weeks of age) by intraperitoneal injection of Avertin (female 0.4 mg/g, male 0.45 mg/g of body weight).
While anesthesia sets in, prepare the catheter for intubation. First, blunt the needle of the catheter by cutting the end with scissors. Then, push the catheter completely over the end of the needle.
Confirm the appropriate level of anesthesia by pedal reflex via firm toe pinching.
Fix the mouse on the intubation platform by hooking its upper incisors over a suture and confirm that the chest is vertical underneath the suture.
Place a fiber optic cable between the front legs to illuminate the chest.
Carefully open the mouth of the mouse and pull out the tongue using disinfected flat forceps. Look for the emission of white light to locate the larynx and visualize the epiglottis and arytenoid cartilages.
Once the opening of the trachea is clearly visible, gently slide the catheter into the trachea. The length of the catheter to be inserted depends on the age and size of the animal, since it should not go below the bifurcation to guarantee an even distribution of lung adenocarcinoma cells within the lung. Quickly remove the needle from the catheter.
The proper placement of the catheter in the trachea is indicated by white light shining through the catheter. To confirm the placement of the catheter in the trachea, attach a 1-mL syringe containing water to the catheter. The water in the syringe will rapidly move up and down in accordance with the breathing.
Pipette 50 μL of the suspension containing 105–106 TU virus per mouse into the center of the catheter hub. The suspension should be aspirated immediately. Subsequently, attach a 1-mL syringe and dispense 300 μL of air to ensure a consistent distribution within the lungs.

Gently remove the catheter, remove the mouse from the intubation platform, and place it on a heat pad until it recovers from anesthesia.
Ten weeks later, sacrifice the mice and isolate the lungs with adenocarcinoma for histological examinations and Tumor derived cell line (TDCL) establishment.
Critical: To ensure that tumors are evenly distributed in the lung, viruses should be evenly distributed within the lungs. We recommend dispensing 300 μL of air to the trachea after pipetting the virus. The concentration of virus and the time should be recorded (Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.3]).

TDCL cell line establishment
Timing: 4 weeks
This section describes how to establish a mouse tumor cell line derived from GEMMs.
Culture primary tumor tissue.
Wash fresh lung tumor tissue with PBS containing 1% penicillin and streptomycin and mince the tissue into approximately 1-mm diameter pieces with scissors.
Digest the minced tumor tissue with 1 mL 0.25% trypsin–EDTA for 15 min at 37°C.
Remove cell aggregates and tissue fragments with a 70-μm cell strainer.
Collect the cells by centrifugation for 5 min at 200 × g, remove the supernatant, resuspend 10000 cells with 500 μL RPMI-1640 complete medium, seed 500 μL cell suspension in 24 well culture plates.
Maintain the cells in 500 μL RPMI 1640 medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS), 100 U/mL penicillin-streptomycin at 37°C in a humidified atmosphere of 5% CO2.
Refresh the tissue culture medium every three days.
Isolate single-cell clones.
Trypsinize subconfluent cell monolayers with 100 μL 0.05% trypsin–EDTA for 2 min at 37°C.
Count the cells, dilute cells to 80 cells per 10 mL and seed 100 μL into 96 wells plates.

Culture the cells for 14 days and pick individual colonies using microscopy.
Mouse subcutaneous allograft injection
Timing: 25 days
This protocol describes how to establish the subcutaneous allograft mouse model and monitor tumor growth in vivo using mouse tumor cells derived from GEMMs.
Expand the cells.
Seed TDCL cells in 10cm well 24 h before transplantation at approximately 50% confluency in RPMI-1640 complete medium. Incubate the cell cultures at 37°C, 5% CO2, and approximately 95% relative humidity.
On the next day, harvest the cells using 1 mL of trypsin-EDTA (0.05% in PBS) at 37°C for 5 min per 10-cm plate and, subsequently, resuspend the detached cells with 9 mL of RPMI-1640 complete medium.
Count the cells in a hemocytometer and transfer the number of cells needed for the experiments in a 50-mL conical centrifuge tube.
Subsequently, centrifuge the cells for 5 min at 300 × g, aspirate the supernatant, and, using a pipette, resuspend the cells at a density of 7.5 × 106/mL (for the injection of 1.5 × 106 TDCL cells per mouse) in PBS.
Keep the cells on ice until transplantation.
Perform subcutaneous injection.
Prepare C57BL/6 male mice at the age of 6–8 weeks.
Mix the cell suspension and subcutaneously implant 200 μL of the suspension containing 1.5 × 106 cells (the number of cells may vary) in the right flank of each mouse.
Once the tumor volume reaches 50–100 mm3 (6–8 days), randomly separate the tumor-bearing mice into two groups.
Note: We recommend using mice of the same genetic background and sex as the donor of tumor cells to guarantee the recipient mice tolerant well to the tumor cells.
Measure the tumor volume.

Determine the tumor volumes by measuring the length (l) and width (w) with a Vernier caliper every other day and calculating the volume with the formula (V = 0.5 × l × w2).
At the end of the experiment (approximately 25 days), the mice are sacrificed, and tumors are isolated by dissection, weighed and used for in vitro experiments.
Note: The mean tumor diameter should not exceed 20 mm according to the tumor burden guideline.
Anti-PD-1 treatment
Timing: 3 weeks
This section describes anti-PD-1 antibody treatment in tumor-bearing mice and how to monitor the tumor volume. We recommend using mice of the same sex and age to reduce individual differences.
Intraperitoneally inject mice with 0.2 mg anti-PD-1 antibody(aPD-1) or Isotype control (IgG) 3 days after inoculation and treat every 3 days.
Monitor the tumor volume with calipers every 2–3 days to ensure that the tumor volume does not exceed the ethical requirements for animal protection.
Tumor-infiltrating lymphocyte isolation
Timing: 1 day
This step included dissection of the tumor tissue, dissociation of the tumor into single-cell suspension and lymphocyte isolation. We recommend using freshly isolated tumor tissue and that the processing time is minimal to ensure cell viability.
Clean and sterilize surgical instruments, filters, and containers.
Sacrifice the mice, dissect the tumors and carefully remove the skin. Cut 0.5 g tumor tissue for lymphocyte isolation, transfer the tumor tissue to a 50-mL tube with 1 mL FBS free DMEM and keep on ice till all the tumor tissue is dissected. It often takes 1 h for one person to dissect 10 mice.
Gently cut the tumor into approximately 1-mm diameter pieces using scissors (perform this step within 2 min).
Prepare the digestion solution
Add 5 mL PBS to sterilized bottle.
Add 50 μL 25 mg/mL Collagenase IV.

Add 20 μL 1 mM DNase I.
Mix well by shaking
Add 5 mL digestion buffer to the 50-mL tube which containing tumor pieces, and incubate the sample in a shaker at 200 rpm for 1 h at 37°C.
Critical: This step should be performed very gently and quickly. Cell viability will decrease sharply if the procedure is too long. Note that the quality of collagenase is also crucial and determines the quantity and activity of cells.
Obtain a single-cell suspension.
Add 15 mL PBS to stop the digestion.
Repeatedly pipette the tissue suspension with a dropper.
Pass the tissue suspension through a 200-mesh filter and then collect the cell suspension.
Lyse blood cells.
Precool the centrifuge to 4°C.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 460 × g for 5 min to collect the cell pellet.
Discard the supernatant, resuspend the cells in 1 mL ACK lysis buffer and place on ice for 1 min.
Add 10 mL PBS to stop the lysis and centrifuge the cell suspension at 460 × g for 5 min.
Prepare 40% (v/v) Percoll gradient solution.
Add 6 mL serum free DMEM to a sterilized bottle.
Add 0.4 mL 10 × PBS.
Add 3.6 mL Percoll.
Mix well by swirling.
Discard the supernatant, resuspend the cells in 10 mL 40% (v/v) Percoll gradient solution, and centrifuge the cell suspension at 550 × g for 35 min.
Carefully remove the supernatant, which contains a large number of tumor cells, with a dropper. The resulting cell pellet is enriched for lymphocytes.
Resuspend the pellet in 10 mL PBS and centrifuge at 460 × g for 5 min to wash the cells.

Discard the supernatant, resuspend the pellets in 1 mL DMEM containing 3% FBS, and count the living cells by trypan blue staining. Transfer equal numbers of living cells (5 × 106 is recommended) to 1.5-mL tubes for further flow cytometry analysis (Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.5]).
Flow cytometry analysis
Timing: 2 days
Day 1
Prepare culture medium with cytokine stimulations reagents.
Add 0.6 mL DMEM with 10% FBS.
Add 0.6 μL 0.5 mg/mL PMA stock.
Add 0.6 μL 1 mM Ionomycin stock.
Add 0.6 μL golgi inhibitor stock.
Mix well by vortexing.
Centrifuge the lymphocytes at 460 × g for 5 min at 4°C, discard the supernatant and resuspend the cell pellets with 600 μL culture medium containing stimulations reagents.
Transfer the cell suspension to a 24-well plate and incubate the cells in 5% CO2 at 37°C for 3 h.
Stain for flow cytometry
Allow lymphocytes to attach to the bottom of the plates, resuspend and transfer the cells to 96-well plates. Centrifuge the 96-well plate at 460 × g for 2 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant. The capacity of a 96 well is 300 μL; therefore, transfer the solution twice to collect all the cells.
During centrifugation, prepare FACS buffer, which is 0.2% BSA (w/v) in PBS.
Resuspend the cells in 200 μL FACS buffer, centrifuge the plate at 460 × g for 2 min at 4°C, and discard the supernatant.
Prepare the antibody solution.

Resuspend the cell pellets in 50 μL antibody and incubate the cells at 25°C for 15 min. Note that the following steps need to be performed away from light.
Centrifuge the plate at 460 × g for 2 min and discard the antibody.

Resuspend the cell pellets in 200 μL FACS buffer, centrifuge the plate at 460 × g for 2 min and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the cells in 150 μL fixation/permeabilization solution and fix the cells at 4°C for 40 min.
Pause Point: The fixed cells can be stored at 4°C for 24 h. Wash the cells with 200 μL FACS buffer, centrifuge and resuspend the cells in 200 μL FACS buffer. The next step can be performed on the second day.
Day 2
Wash the cells with 200 μL of 1× perm/wash buffer, centrifuge the plate at 460 × g for 2 min, and discard the supernatant.
Prepare the antibody solution.

Resuspend the cell pellets in 50 μL antibody solution and incubate the cells at 4°C for 1 h.
Centrifuge the plates at 460 × g for 2 min, discard the antibody, and wash the cells with 200 μL FACS buffer.
Centrifuge and resuspend the cells in 200 μL FACS buffer. Pass the cell suspension through a 200-mesh filter and analyze with a BD Verse cytometer.
Refer to Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3] for the gating strategy. We recommend collecting 10,000 CD8+ T cells for further analysis (Troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.7]).
Note: Isotype control is recommended for cytokine staining, it helps you estimate the non-specific binding. For markers that are clearly bimodal, such as CD45 and CD8, there is no need to set up isotype controls.
Immunofluorescence analysis of CD8+ T cells
Timing: 2 days
Day 1
This protocol describes how to process tumor tissue into slices and perform CD8+ T cell immunofluorescence to evaluate CD8+ T cell infiltration per tumor area.
Embed the tissue.
Fix the freshly isolated tumor tissues with 1% paraformaldehyde (PFA) at 4°C for 12 h.

Critical: For CD8 staining, the concentration of PFA is critical, and over 2% will result in a weak CD8 signal (Liu et al., 2015[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]).
Incubate the tissue with PBS (2 h), PBS with 15% sucrose (w/v) (2 h) and PBS with 30% sucrose (8 h) until the tissues are fully dehydrated.
Place the dehydrated tissue in an embedding box, add OCT until the tissue is fully covered and seal the box. Incubate at 4°C for 12 h.
Snap freeze the tissue.
Obtain dry ice and transfer to a foam box; press the embedding box on the dry ice to create a box-shaped groove.
Place the box with tissue into the groove and freeze for 20 min.
Store the tissue at −20°C after OCT fully freezes.
Obtain tissue sections.
Cut the tissue into 5-μm-thick slices with a cryostat and transfer to a glass slide.
Incubate the slices at 25°C for 2 h to dry.
Store the slices at −20°C.
Perform immunostaining of tissue sections.
Add 500 μL PBS to the tissue section, let stand, and wash for 10 min.
Discard the liquid by vacuum, draw lines on both sides of the tissue with a PAP pen, and wash with PBS again.
Place the slices in a humidified box, add a drop of image enhancer (Invitrogen, CAT: I36933), and incubate at 25°C for 30 min.
Rinse the slices with PBS and permeabilize with 0.3% (v/v) Triton X-100 in PBS (PBS-Triton) at 25°C for 30 min.
Prepare the antibody solution; mix well by vortex.

Add 100 μL antibody solution to the slice and incubate in a humidified box at 4°C for 12 h
Critical: Do not perform antigen retrieval as the CD8 signal will be completely lost.
Day 2
Discard the antibody and rinse the slices with PBS-Triton four times.

Add a drop of mounting medium, place the coverslip on the slices and seal with nail polish.
Obtain whole tumor images by stitching images collected with a 10 X objective. Scan the sections by an Olympus FV3000 confocal system with a 60× silicone oil objective to get zoom in images. (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A). Troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.9]
Western blot analysis
Timing: 2 days
Lyse the tumor tissues.
Homogenize and sonicate the tissue in 500 μL RIPA buffer in the presence of 1% (v/v) protease inhibitor cocktail and 2% (v/v) PMSF on ice. The freshly dissected tumor tissue can be stored at −80°C for few months.
Centrifuge at 12,000 × g for 15 min at 4°C and collect the supernatant.
Determine protein concentrations using the Pierce BCA Protein Assay Kit according to the manufacturer’s instructions: https://www.thermofisher.com/order/catalog/product/23227#/23227[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/order/catalog/product/23227#/23227]. Heat the protein at 98°C for 5 min with 4× loading buffer.
Separate the sample by SDS-PAGE and transfer to PVDF membranes using the Trans-Blot Turbo Transfer System.
Perform immunostaining.
Block the membranes in 5% nonfat milk (Bio-Rad, USA) for 1 h at 25°C .
Incubate the membranes with primary antibodies diluted in TBS-T (0.1% Tween) supplemented with 3% BSA at 4°C for 12 h.
Wash the membranes with TBS-T 4 times.
Incubate the membranes with fluorescent secondary antibodies for 1 h at 25°C.
Wash the membranes and visualize the bands using the Odyssey CLx imaging system.
